title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Tribe should now receive full Federal recognition. The Lumbee Tribe, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, should now be entitled to full Federal recognition with benefits, privileges, and immunities accorded to them as an Indian tribe. The Lumbee Tribe, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, should now be entitled to full Federal recognition with benefits, privileges, and immunities accorded to them as an Indian tribe under SEC. 3. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. All laws and regulations applicable to Indians and Indian tribes will apply to the Lumbee Tribe and its members. Additionally, Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe and its members will be eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. Members residing in specific North Carolina counties will be considered as residing near an Indian tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted Federal recognition, allowing its members to access services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. Members residing in certain North Carolina counties are considered to be living near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior will verify the tribal roll to determine the service population and develop a budget for eligible services. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's tribal roll, as of the enactment date, defines the service population for Federal services, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. Fee lands in Robeson County, NC, sought for conveyance to the US will be treated as on-reservation trust acquisitions. North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by or held in trust for the Lumbee Tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's tribal lands in the state are subject to jurisdiction for criminal offenses and civil actions. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the State of North Carolina after consulting with the Attorney General. The provisions do not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act, and funds are authorized for implementing the Act.
